M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 2, as the defendant conducts business in Massachusetts and the events giving rise to this action occurred in Lynn, Massachusetts.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the Premises where the conduct and injuries occurred is located in Lynn, Massachusetts.

M.G.L. c. 148, \u00a7 26E.proposition: Massachusetts law, including M.G.L. c. 148, § 26E, requires landlords of residential apartment buildings to install and maintain operational smoke detectors in common areas, including hallways.

780 CMR \u00a7 28.proposition: The Massachusetts Building Code (780 CMR § 28) also mandates that smoke alarms must function properly in residential buildings.

See *Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*,.raw_text: See *Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 378 Mass. 177, 181 (1979) (property owners owe a duty of reasonable care).
See *Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*,.proposition: Defendant Lynn Apartment Management, LLC, owed a duty of care under Massachusetts law to keep its property in a reasonably safe condition, including maintaining operational smoke detectors in common areas as required by law.
See *Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*,.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurring opinion by Justice Kaplan focused on the treatment of trespassers and the abolition of common-law status distinctions, not on the general duty of property owners to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition or specifically to maintain smoke detectors. It does not mention Soule, Massachusetts Elec. Co., or articulate the general duty of reasonable care owed by property owners under Massachusetts law. Therefore, based on this text alone, it does not support the cited proposition.
See *Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*,.relevant_excerpt: Concurring, I must, in contrast to the Chief Justice, express disappointment at the intimation in the next-to-last paragraph of the court’s opinion that the liability of an occupier for negligence might still be made to turn in this jurisdiction on the mere circumstance, without more, that the plaintiff had the common law status of a so called trespasser at the time of the occurrence in suit.

See also *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Superma.raw_text: See also *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 783-84 (2007) (statutory duties inform scope of negligence).
See also *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Superma.proposition: Defendant further owed a statutory duty under M.G.L. c. 148, § 26E, to ensure that smoke detectors were properly installed and operational in common areas of the Premises.
See also *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Superma.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
See also *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Superma.support_reasoning: The Sheehan opinion deals exclusively with common‑law premises liability and the adoption of the mode‑of‑operation approach in slip‑and‑fall cases at supermarkets. It does not mention M.G.L. c. 148, § 26E, smoke detectors, statutory safety duties, or any analogous statutory duty regarding conditions in residential premises. It therefore cannot be used as authority that a defendant owed a statutory duty under c. 148, § 26E, to ensure smoke detectors were properly installed and operational in common areas.
See also *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Superma.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule governing premises liability requiring a plaintiff to prove that an owner had either actual or constructive notice of an unsafe condition on the premises. However, if a plaintiff proves that an unsafe condition on an owner’s premises exists that was reasonably foreseeable, resulting from an owner’s self-service business or mode of operation, and the plaintiff slips as a result of the unsafe condition, the plaintiff will satisfy the notice requirement.”

See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457.raw_text: See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 373 (2010) (negligence established by failure to take reasonable steps to correct known hazards).
See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457.proposition: Defendant's failure to repair the smoke detector constitutes a violation of its statutory and common-law duties and exemplifies a lack of reasonable care.
See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos concerns premises liability for snow and ice and abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction, reaffirming that negligence is established by failure to use reasonable care to address known hazards on property. It does not discuss smoke detectors, statutory safety-device obligations, or any statutory duty at all; its duty analysis is purely common-law negligence in a slip-and-fall context. Thus it can be cited for the general reasonable-care standard toward known hazards, but not for the specific proposition that failure to repair a smoke detector violates statutory and common-law duties.
See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457.relevant_excerpt: “If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.” 457 Mass. at 383.

See *Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 7.raw_text: See *Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 745, 764 (1984) (proximate cause established if harm is foreseeable).
See *Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 7.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of the defendant’s negligent conduct, the plaintiff suffered smoke inhalation injuries, requiring medical treatment, time away from work, and significant emotional and financial harm.
See *Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses proximate cause and states that causation is generally a jury question, satisfied where the harm is a reasonably foreseeable consequence of the negligence. The court upholds that the police officers’ negligent failure to remove an intoxicated driver can be found to have proximately caused the plaintiffs’ injuries that followed within minutes, emphasizing foreseeability. This directly supports the general proposition that injuries (including those requiring medical treatment and causing other harms) may be a direct and proximate result of negligent conduct when they are foreseeable consequences.
See *Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Similarly, ‘[t]he question of causation is generally one of fact for the jury…. A plaintiff need only show “that there was greater likelihood or probability that the harm complained of was due to causes for which the defendant was responsible than from any other cause.”’ … ‘It is only necessary for the plaintiff to prove that the defendant took a risk with respect to the plaintiff's safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ … The injuries suffered by the plaintiffs… could be found that they were reasonably foreseeable consequences….”
